children.name: query
children.definition: a question, often expressing doubt about sth or looking for an answer from an authority :khúc mắc
examples: If anyone has a query I’ll deal with it at the end of the meeting.
I would be happy to answer people’s queries if they write to me at my home address.

children.name: query about
examples: Give us a ring if youhaveanyqueriesabout the contract.
Staff are always available toansweryourqueries.

children.name: raise a queryask a questionđưa ra khúc mắc
examples: One of the students raised a query about the marking system.

children.name: the jury is (still) out
children.definition: If  on a subject, people do not yet know the answer or have a definiteopinion about it
examples: _The jury's still outonthe safety of irradiated food.

children.name: challenge
children.definition: verbDOUBTnghi ngờ

children.name: to question whethersomethingis true or legal
examples: _Children challenge their parents' authority far more nowadays than they did in the past.

children.name: cast doubt on sth
children.definition: cast doubt onsth nghi ngờ

children.name: to make something seem uncertain
examples: _Witnesses have cast doubt on the suspect's innocence.

children.name: challenge
children.definition: nounQUESTION

children.name: sb who tends to doubt sb or sth
cynical
children.definition: disapproving sb who is cynical is not willing to believe that people have good or honest reasons for doing sth :đa nghi, hay hoài nghi
examples: I think movie stars just do charity work to get publicity - but maybe I’m too cynical.
cynic[C]
Cynics say that Christmas is nothing more than a way for stores to make money.
cynicism[U]
The public’s cynicism about politics is at an all time high.

children.name: cynical view
examples: an author with a cynical view of life.
I think she takes a rather cynicalviewof men.

children.name: cynical about
examples: Since her divorce, she’s become very cynical about men.
I've always beendeeplycynicalaboutpoliticians.

children.name: sceptical
children.definition: /skepticalUS  tending to disagree with what other people tell you : hayhoài nghi
examples: When I started this investigation I was sceptical.
His attitude towards all religion is sceptical.
scepticism/skepticismUS [U]
His latest theories have met with a lot of scepticism.
sceptic/skepticUS [C]
There are a lot of skeptics out there, but I think the women’s basketball program will be asuccess.

children.name: sceptical about/of
examples: I’m extremely sceptical about what I read in the press.
Environmental groups are sceptical of the government’s claims.
Many expertsremainscepticalabout/ofhis claims.

children.name: highly/deeply sceptical
examples: He is highly sceptical of the reforms.
‘You can trust me,’ he said. Jane looked sceptical.

children.name: doubt
children.definition: to think that sb may not really be telling the truth, even though you are not completely sure: nghi ngờ, ngờ vực
examples: doubt sbto not trust or have confidence in sb :
He wondered how he could ever have doubted her.
I never doubted myself. I always knew I could play tennis at this level.
She loved him, and had never doubted him.
doubt sb’s word(= think that sb is lying)
I have no reason to doubt his word
He's never lied to me before, so I have no reason to doubt his word.

children.name: suspicion
children.definition: the feeling that you cannot trust sb, even though you may not know exactly why:sự nghi ngờ, ngờ vực, hoài nghi

children.name: Terry’s grandmother looked at me with suspicion and demanded, ‘Who’s this?’
examples: When I asked about Gerald, Susan’s usually kind face clouded with fear and suspicion.

children.name: treat/ regard sb with suspicion
examples: She alwaystreateduswith suspicion.
People moving into the area are oftenregarded with suspicion.
Since they discovered the truth about his background, his colleagues have regarded him with suspicion.

children.name: harbour suspicions of(= has)
examples: They feel that she harbours suspicions of their politics.

children.name: doubt
children.definition: to think thatsthmay not really be true, even though you are not completely sure:nghi ngờ, ngờ vực
examples: In all the years I knew him I never once doubted his story.
Kim never doubted his story.
doubter[C] sb who thinks that sth is probably not true
I hope to convince any doubters in the audience that our policies will work.

children.name: doubt (that)
examples: He doubted that the car was hers because everyone knew she had no money.
I doubt we’ll ever see him again.

children.name: doubt whether/if
examples: They seriously doubted whether the letter had ever existed.

children.name: doubt if/whether
examples: You can complain, but I doubt if it’ll make any difference.

children.name: I doubt itspoken nghi lắm
examples: He may be able to do a good job, but I doubt it.

children.name: ‘Do you think there’ll be any tickets left?’ ‘I doubt it(= I don’t think so ).’
examples: doubt very much/seriouslydoubtthink sth is almost certainly not true:
She says she’ll leave him, but I doubt very much that she will.

children.name: suspicious
children.definition: feelingthat you should not trust someone or something, although you arenotsurewhy: ngờ vực
examples: His colleagues became suspicious (= thought that there was something wrong) when he did not appear at work, since he was always punctual.
My mother has a very suspicious nature (= does not trust people) .

children.name: be suspicious of
examples: I’m always suspicious of people who offer me money.

children.name: deeply/highlysuspiciousvery suspicious
examples: She had no proof at all, but nonetheless was deeply suspicious of her former friend’s motives.
They arehighlysuspiciousofone another/ofeach other's motives.

children.name: suspect
children.definition: to think that sth is not honest or true : nghi ngờ
examples: I have no reason to suspect her honesty/ loyalty.
We suspected his motives in making his offer.
I began to suspect his motives in inviting me.

children.name: question
children.definition: to have or express doubts about whether sth is true, good, necessary etc : đặt dấu hỏi, nghi ngờ, thắc mắc
examples: I questioned the wisdom of taking so many pills.
questioning[adj] a questioning look or expression shows that you have doubts about something or need some information :
Mrs Carson gave Ruth a questioning look.
questioninglyadverb

children.name: question what/how/when etc
examples: Are you questioning what I’m saying?
No one dared to question his decisions.

children.name: question whether
examples: One questions whether he’s telling the truth.
Results from a study questioned whether treatment with the drug really improved survival.

children.name: dubious
children.definition: probably not honest, true, right etc : đáng ngờ
examples: The firm was accused of dubious accounting practices.
Many critics regard this argument as dubious or, at best, misleading.
The assumption that growth in one country benefits the whole world ishighly dubious.
These claims are dubious and not scientifically proven.
He has been associated with some dubious characters.

children.name: I’m not sure
children.definition: (about that)spoken use this in order to say politely that you think what sb has said is unlikely:
examples: ‘I think Kate and Eddie will end up getting married.’ ‘Really? I’m not sure about that.’

children.name: I wouldn’t have thought
children.definition: spoken say this when you think that sth is unlikely to happen or be true, especially when you are not completely sure that you are right: tôi không nghĩ
examples: I wouldn’t have thought (that)
I wouldn’t have thought that there would be much traffic on a Sunday morning.
Tôi không nghĩ rằng sẽ có nhiều xe cộ lưu thông vào một buổi sáng chủ nhật.
I wouldn’t have thought so
‘Will John and Carmen be coming tonight?’ ‘I wouldn’t have thought so. They’re very busy at the moment.’

children.name: I’d be surprised if
children.definition: spoken say this when you think something is very unlikely to happen or is very unlikely to be true:
examples: I’d be surprised if they get here in time for the show.
I’d be very surprised if Ronnie got the job -- he just doesn’t have enough experience.

children.name: don’t think
children.definition: /ˌdəʊnt ˈθɪŋk/
examples: don’t think (that) không nghĩ là
▪At first I didn’t think that Jim was going to reply.
▪ I don’t think many people will come to the meeting, do you?
don’t think so không nghĩ như vậy
▪ ‘Do we have any coffee left?’ ‘I don’t think so -- I’ll have a look.’
▪ ‘Is Mr Brown there?’ ‘No, I don’t think so, I saw him go out earlier.’

children.name: be doubtful
children.definition: doubtful probably not likely to happen or besuccessful:
examples: Prospects for a lasting peace remain doubtful.
Already the whole scheme was looking increasingly doubtful.

children.name: it is doubtful if/whether
examples: It was doubtful whether the patient would survive the operation.

children.name: it is doubtful that
examples: It is doubtful that the missing airmen will ever be found.

children.name: dubious
children.definition: not good or not of good quality :
examples: The room was decorated in dubious taste.

children.name: doubtful
children.definition: probably not goodSYN dubious:
examples: Here the tap water is of doubtful quality.

children.name: not sure that sth is a good idea
be doubtful
children.definition: doubtful not sure that sth is true or right :
examples: ‘Everything’s going to be all right, you’ll see.’ Jennylooked doubtful.

children.name: doubtful if/whether
examples: I’m still doubtful whether I should accept this job.

children.name: doubtful about (doing) sth
examples: At first we were doubtful about employing Charlie.

children.name: be dubious
children.definition: dubious not sure whether sth is good or trueSYN doubtful:
examples: I can see you are dubious; take some time to think about it.
‘Are you sure you know what you are doing?’ Andy said,looking dubious.
‘Do you think they’ll let us in?’ Gabby looked dubious.

children.name: dubious about
examples: Some universities are dubious about accepting students over the age of 30.
Marian is still dubious about whether any of the government’s ‘solutions’ will work.

children.name: I'm dubiousabouthis promises to change his ways
reservation
children.definition: a feeling of doubt because you do not agree completely with a plan, idea, or suggestion : dè dặt , e dè
examples: without reservation
We condemn their actionswithout reservation
He accepted my advicewithoutreservation.
reservation about
Workers and employees shared deep reservationsaboutthe wisdom of the government's plans for the industry.

children.name: have reservations
examples: I have reservations about her work.

children.name: express reservations
children.definition: say that you have reservations
examples: I did not think it wise to express my reservations.

children.name: some/certain reservations
examples: Despite some reservations, I recommend this book.

children.name: serious/grave reservations
examples: They had serious reservations about the plan.

children.name: strong reservations
examples: Five of the committee members expressed strong reservations about the product's safety.

children.name: considerable reservations
examples: We have considerable reservations about the government's economic proposals.

children.name: a minor reservation
children.definition: not serious or important
examples: I voted "yes", although I had a few minor reservations

children.name: a major reservation
children.definition: serious or important
examples: We have major reservations about his ability to do the job.

children.name: mixed feelings
children.definition: if you have mixed feelings about something, you feel both good and bad things about them :

children.name: have mixed feelings
examples: I have very mixed feelings about moving house – it’s exciting but I’ll miss this area.
I had mixed feelings about leaving home. I was excited but at the same time, I knew I would miss my family.

children.name: second thoughts
children.definition: have to start having doubts about whether a decision you have just made is the right one :
examples: I liked the dress in the shop, but when I got it home I had second thoughts.

children.name: misgiving
children.definition: a feeling of doubt or worry about a future event: mối nghi ngại
examples: Many teachers expressed serious misgivings about the new exams.
My only misgiving is that we might not have enough time to do the job properly.
have misgivingsto feel worried about doing something, because it may have a bad result :
Ralph had serious misgivings about changing his career at the age of 50.
